The Nation’s 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, The Nation Fund for Independent Journalism, reported $419,309 in revenue, from contributions, grants, and investment income, according to its 2022 Form 990 filing with the federal Internal Revenue Service. The

sources.description: The website of the global edition of British weekly magazine The Spectator, which offers commentary from a conservative perspective.
sources.ownership_summary: TheSpectator.com is published by The Spectator (1828) Limited, a privately held British company that also publishes the British edition of The Spectator. The Spectator (1828) Limited, in turn, is owned by May Corporation Limited, an offshore company in Jersey, a British Crown Dependency. That company is ultimately owned by British billionaire Frederick Barclay, who also owns the U.K.’s Daily Telegraph newspaper, international art magazine Apollo, and online retailer Very. The Spectator (1828) Limited also operates Apollo magazine, which publishes news about visual arts. The site derives revenue from advertising and features a paywall for unlimited access. In 2022, the website changed its domain name from SpectatorWorld.com to TheSpectator.com, according to records maintained by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers.

sources.description: The website of Time, a weekly news magazine that is one of the most celebrated and recognized U.S. periodicals, known for special editions like “Person of the Year” and the “Time 100.”
sources.ownership_summary: Time is owned by billionaire and Salesforce.com founder Marc Benioff and his wife, Lynne Benioff, who purchased the magazine from Meredith Corp. for $190 million in late 2018. Benioff, whose worth was placed at $7.35 billion in late August 2022 by the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, said that he planned to support the magazine financially but would not interfere in editorial decision-making. “Lynne and I will take on no operational responsibility for Time, and look only to be stewards of this historic and iconic brand with all of us,” Benioff said in a statement posted on Time.com in September 2018. In 2022 interviews with Axios, editor Edward Felsenthal underscored that the couple is not involved in editorial decisions. He also said that Marc Benioff’s financial goals include exceeding $200 million in revenue in 2022 and ultimately becoming profitable, potentially generating $1 billion in annual revenue and becoming the world’s “number one media brand.” Time.com earns revenue largely th

sources.description: A conservative news and commentary site that has published some false and misleading claims about U.S. elections, the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, the COVID-19 pandemic, and other issues.
sources.ownership_summary: Townhall is the flagship website of Townhall Media, a political news publisher that runs the content of other conservative sites, including HotAir.com, RedState.com, Twitchy.com, BearingArms.com, and PJMedia.com. Townhall Media is owned by Salem Media Group (formerly Salem Communications), a publicly traded company headquartered in Camarillo, California, that describes itself as “a leading U.S. radio and Internet broadcaster reaching audiences interested in Christian and family-themed content and conservative values.” Salem Media Group owns approximately 100 radio stations across the United States, according to its website, most of which are Christian talk stations, news talk stations, and contemporary Christian music stations. The company also owns more than a dozen Christian content websites, a publishing arm, Biblical-themed mobile apps, several investment advice sites, and a natural supplement e- commerce site. Townhall earns revenue through advertising and subscriptions.

sources.description: The website for USA Today, a national newspaper that is one of the most widely read dailies in the United States. The website publishes global news and local stories from Gannett-owned newspapers.
sources.ownership_summary: USA Today is owned by the publicly traded, McLean, Virginia-based Gannett Co., Inc. In November 2019, GateHouse Media, and its parent company, New Media Investment Corp., acquired Gannett for approximately $1.1 billion in cash and stock, creating the largest newspaper chain in the U.S. with more than 260 daily newspapers. USA Today is the flagship publication of the chain, which is called Gannett Co. and also features papers such as the Arizona Republic and the Detroit Free Press. Gannett also owns Newsquest, a company of more than 165 newspaper brands and 40 magazines in the United Kingdom. In the U.S. and the U.K., Gannett generates revenue through advertisements and subscriptions for its printed publications, websites, and other digital products.

sources.description: The website of Vanity Fair, a culture, politics, and fashion magazine known for celebrity profiles, long- form reporting, and provocative photography.
sources.ownership_summary: VanityFair.com is part of Condé Nast, a subsidiary of the privately held media company Advance Publications, Inc. Advance’s other brands include The New Yorker, Vogue, GQ, American City Business Journals, and local newspapers throughout the U.S. The company also owns Turnitin, a company that provides plagiarism-detection software and other educational tools, and holds significant stakes in the telecom giant Charter Communications and entertainment company Warner Bros. Discovery. In recent years, substantial magazine losses have brought layoffs throughout Condé Nast, including the closing of Details and of the print versions of Teen Vogue and Self. In 2019, Condé Nast sold Golf Digest and W magazine. In 2022, Condé Nast announced it would close Vogue Russia due to the war in Ukraine. VanityFair.com generates revenue through advertising, sponsored content, and print and online subscriptions.

sources.description: A website that states it was founded to address what it called the gap between reporting and the audience’s understanding of that reporting, which it often does from a liberal perspective.
sources.ownership_summary: Vox.com is owned by Vox Media, Inc., a privately held company whose investors include NBCUniversal, General Atlantic, Accel, Comcast Ventures, the Rockefeller Foundation, and Khosla Ventures. Vox Media also owns The Verge, SB Nation, Polygon, Eater, and Curbed. In September 2019, Vox Media merged with New York Media, the owner of New York Magazine, Intelligencer, The Cut, Vulture, Grub Street, and The Strategist. Neither company disclosed the value of the deal. Vox Media hosts and sells advertising for other sites, such as Funny Or Die and Bill Simmons’ The Ringer, and for other publishers in revenue-sharing agreements. The company licenses Chorus, its publishing platform, to other publishers, which use the platform to create stories, keep track of readership, and disperse content on social media. Vox Media also has a partnership with Netflix for a series called “Explained,” and partnerships with PBS and CNN for TV shows tied to its other websites.Recode’s tech-conference business also

sources.description: A website that covers national politics and policy from a right-of-center viewpoint, owned by a billionaire who funds conservative politicians and causes.
sources.ownership_summary: The Washington Examiner is owned by The Washington Newspaper Publishing Company LLC, which does business as MediaDC and is a subsidiary of Clarity Media Group, a holding company owned by billionaire Philip Anschutz, who built fortunes in the fossil fuel, railroad, telecom, and entertainment industries and has invested heavily in wind energy. Anschutz also owns stakes in professional sports teams, the Staples Center in Los Angeles, the Coachella music festival, and vacation resorts. Anschutz donated over $1.5 million to Republican candidates and committees in the 2016 election cycle, approximately $400,000 in the 2020 cycle, approximately $3.3 million as of September 2022, and approximately $10,000 as of October 2023.His foundation, the Anschutz Foundation, has given money to a variety of conservative political groups, including the pro-business American Legislative Exchange Council, the libertarian and conservative advocacy group Americans for Prosperity, anti-marijuana legalization gr

sources.description: The website for The Washington Post, a leading daily newspaper owned by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, publishing local, national, and international news and in-depth analysis.
sources.ownership_summary: The Post was owned for decades by the Graham family. In 2013, Donald Graham, son of the late publisher and CEO Katharine Graham, announced the sale of the Post to Jeff Bezos for a reported $250 million. WashingtonPost.com generates revenue through advertising and subscriptions. Users without digital subscriptions can only access a limited number of articles on the site.

sources.description: The website of The Washington Times, a national daily newspaper owned by the Unification Church, which has published some inaccurate or misleading claims about U.S. politics and COVID-19.
sources.ownership_summary: The Washington Times has been owned by the Unification Church through multiple, privately held companies since the paper was founded in 1982. Church founder Reverend Sun Myung Moon, a self-described messiah and cult leader- like figure who died in 2012, invested more than $1 billion in The Washington Times during its first 20 years. Operations Holdings, Inc. owns The Washington Times LLC (the paper’s publisher) through one of its subsidiaries, TWT Holdings, LLC, which was registered in 2010. All three are incorporated in Delaware. The Unification Church owns Operations Holdings, Inc. It also owns or controls hotels, schools, and other media outlets and businesses, which the church says have generated tens of millions of dollars each year. The Washington Times earns revenue from advertising, sponsored content, and subscriptions.

sources.description: A website that covers national politics and policy from a right-of-center viewpoint, owned by a billionaire who funds conservative politicians and causes.
sources.ownership_summary: The Washington Examiner is owned by The Washington Newspaper Publishing Company LLC, which does business as MediaDC and is a subsidiary of Clarity Media Group, a holding company owned by billionaire Philip Anschutz, who built fortunes in the fossil fuel, railroad, telecom, and entertainment industries and has invested heavily in wind energy. Anschutz also owns stakes in professional sports teams, the Staples Center in Los Angeles, the Coachella music festival, and vacation resorts. Anschutz donated over $1.5 million to Republican candidates and committees in the 2016 election cycle, approximately $400,000 in the 2020 cycle, approximately $3.3 million as of September 2022, and approximately $10,000 as of October 2023.His foundation, the Anschutz Foundation, has given money to a variety of conservative political groups, including the pro-business American Legislative Exchange Council, the libertarian and conservative advocacy group Americans for Prosperity, anti-marijuana legalization gr

sources.description: The website of The Wall Street Journal, a daily newspaper founded in 1889 covering politics, global financial markets, the economy, lifestyle, and arts.
sources.ownership_summary: Dow Jones publishes The Wall Street Journal, which is owned by the public media conglomerate News Corp, controlled by the Murdoch family. News Corp also owns Barron’s, MarketWatch, HarperCollins, the New York Post, and other media entities. Murdoch also owns Fox Corporation. In addition to producing its print and digital editions, The Wall Street Journal hosts conferences for business leaders. The site is financed through advertisements, subscriptions, and sales of the publication’s other products, according to News Corp’s annual report. Much of the site’s content is only accessible to paid subscribers.

sources.description: A pro-Russia, anti-Western political and financial blog that has frequently published false or egregiously misleading claims about U.S. and international politics.
sources.ownership_summary: Zero Hedge’s founder is Daniel Ivandjiiski, a Bulgarian-born former hedge fund analyst who started the blog after FINRA, the U.S. financial industry’s regulator, barred him for insider trading, according to New York Magazine and other outlets. The website’s copyright lists a company called ABC Media LTD as its owner. According to a 2012 court document, a search for Zero Hedge in a domain-registry database found that ABC Media LTD was based in Bulgaria. In response to a 2018 NewsGuard email to a general address on the site, an unnamed spokesperson said that the website is “100% employee owned and has never received outside funding.” Despite that statement, ZeroHedge runs advertisements and solicits donations through a Donate page. As of October 2024, the website also offered a monthly or annual subscription to receive content or commentary, or a “professional” subscription that would provide access to Zero Hedge’s “research database.”
